closer and saw the optimizations have not hit master yet.

messages.text: <@U89GY9W1J> I see that Salsa.jl hasn't had any commits in a while. Is this because it's feature complete and doesn't need any attention? Is it okay to depend on it?

elements.text: I see that Salsa.jl hasn't had any commits in a while. Is this because it's feature complete and doesn't need any attention? Is it okay to depend on it?

messages.text:
Thanks for the question, <@U8D9768Q6>!

:sob:  it's because we got lazy, and started working on some internal features, and someone cloned Salsa back into our monorepo and added the features there, and now the open source repo is out of date with our monorepo! :sob:

elements.text: Thanks for the question,

it's because we got lazy, and started working on some internal features, and someone cloned Salsa back into our monorepo and added the features there, and now the open source repo is out of date with our monorepo!

messages.text:
I've been asking the team to put some effort into publishing those changes back into the open source repo and deleting the internal one so we can be in sync again, but it's low priority because we didn't think anyone had any interest in it anyway.

If you think there's interest, we can definitely do that!! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

messages.text:
I have a fork of Traitor.jl up and running, but it does some stuff with generated functions to decide method dispatch that I beleive is not technically kosher. It's observing state created by one generated function in another generated function, e.g. a simple example of the pattern would be
```julia> @generated foo() = Int[1]
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> @generated function bar(x)
           v = foo()
           quote
               x .+ $v
           end
       end
bar (generic function with 1 method)

julia> bar(1)
1-element Vector{Int64}:
 2

julia> push!(foo(), 2)
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 1
 2

julia> bar(1)
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 2
 3

julia>  foo()
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 1
 2```
This pattern is really handy for compiling away the Trait dispatch, but I suspect can blow up in my face quite easily

elements.text: I have a fork of Traitor.jl up and running, but it does some stuff with generated functions to decide method dispatch that I beleive is not technically kosher. It's observing state created by one generated function in another generated function, e.g. a simple example of the pattern would be

julia> @generated foo() = Int[1]
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> @generated function bar(x)
           v = foo()
           quote
               x .+ $v
           end
       end
bar (generic function with 1 method)

julia> bar(1)
1-element Vector{Int64}:
 2

julia> push!(foo(), 2)
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 1
 2

julia> bar(1)
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 2
 3

julia>  foo()
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 1
 2
This pattern is really handy for compiling away the Trait dispatch, but I suspect can blow up in my face quite easily

messages.text:
Salsa is:
• a memoization framework, with
• runtime dependency tracking, so that
• you can update some inputs and (performantly) automatically invalidate the affected caches.
I think that's the best way to think about it.

So any julia functions that have side effects or do things outside the dependency tracking, won't jive with the model. So that might be what you were referring to, <@U6A936746>?

messages.text: Does Relational's version of Salsa let me have a mutable derived input that'll update dependant code once I mutate that derived input?

elements.text: Does Relational's version of Salsa let me have a mutable derived input that'll update dependant code once I mutate that derived input?

messages.text:
no, sadly no mutability allowed. You'd have to encode your data in a way that Salsa can understand, basically by sharding it and writing it into a Salsa mapped input.

We _are_ working on some techniques to simplify that process a bit, so that you can automatically split out the pieces of the input that you care about, but still, no support for mutability. Everything needs to be immutable.

elements.text:

We
are

working on some techniques to simplify that process a bit, so that you can automatically split out the pieces of the input that you care about, but still, no support for mutability. Everything needs to be immutable.

messages.text: (hehe which is why we also have this nice performant immutable dictionaries package: <https://github.com/RelationalAI-oss/MuttsDicts.jl|MuttsDicts.jl>)

MuttsDicts.jl
